revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1974|chess}} Events in [[chess]] in 1974;
==Top players==
[[FIDE]] top 10 by [[Elo rating]] - January 1974
# [[Bobby Fischer]] {{USA}} 2780 # [[Anatoly Karpov]] {{URS}} 2660 # [[Mikhail Tal]] {{URS}} 2660 # [[Boris Spassky]] {{URS}} 2655 # [[Viktor Korchnoi]] {{URS}} 2650 # [[Lajos Portisch]] {{HUN}} 2650 # [[Tigran Petrosian]] {{URS}} 2640 # [[Mikhail Botvinnik]] {{URS}} 2630 # [[Lev Polugaevsky]] {{URS}} 2625 # [[Bent Larsen]] {{DEN}} 2620
==Chess news in brief== *The meteoric rise of [[Anatoly Karpov]] continues to hold the attention of the chess world, as he chalks up win after win in the latest [[World Chess Championship|world championship]] qualifying cycle. His Moscow based, Candidates' quarter-final match against [[Lev Polugaevsky]], is a one-sided affair and Karpov emerges the victor by 5½-2½. In the other candidates' quarter-final matches, [[Viktor Korchnoi]] beats [[Henrique Mecking]] in [[Augusta, Georgia]], [[Tigran Petrosian]] beats [[Lajos Portisch]] in [[Palma de Mallorca]], and [[Boris Spassky]] beats [[Robert Byrne (chess player)|Robert Byrne]] in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. In the semi-finals, Korchnoi defeats Petrosian by 3½-1½ in [[Odessa]], while Karpov is again utterly convincing, winning 7-4 against Spassky in [[Leningrad]]. The battle between Karpov and Korchnoi in the (Moscow) final proves to be a tense and difficult struggle, although the younger man ultimately triumphs 12½-11½, amidst a large number of draws. As the winning candidate, Karpov is scheduled to meet [[Bobby Fischer]] for a world championship decider in 1975 and for his efforts in 1974, is awarded his second successive Chess Oscar. Meanwhile, Fischer puts forward a plan to [[FIDE]] for the conditions of the title match. Running to 179 numbered paragraphs, each of his conditions are acceptable to all parties, except for two. The rejected conditions concern the match being of unlimited length (first to win 10 games, regardless of draws) and that the title stays with the holder in the event of the score reaching 9-9. Fischer insists he will not back down on these stipulations and threatens to resign his title if they are not accepted. He has until April 1975 to finally decide. *[[Evgeny Vasiukov]] excels at [[Manila]], winning the tournament with 10½/14, ahead of Tigran Petrosian (9½/14) and [[Bent Larsen]] (9/14). *[[Montilla-Moriles]] is won by [[Ivan Radulov]] with 5½/9. In joint second place are [[Lubomir Kavalek]] and [[Helmut Pfleger]] (both 5/9). Oddly, the winner is the lowest rated of the ten contestants and while there is a large percentage of draws, many of the games are exciting and worthy of such a strong competition. *The 14th IBM tournament is held at [[Amsterdam]] and is a close run affair, with three grandmasters all sharing first place. [[Borislav Ivkov]], [[Vladimir Tukmakov]] and [[Vlastimil Jansa]] score an identical 10/15. As with the Manila and Montilla tournaments, the entrants are all titled players, making for one of the strongest events of the year. *The [[Nice]] [[Chess Olympiad|Olympiad]] is held at the Palais des Expositions. Offering an enormous playing arena, the venue should surpass those of recent years, but a lack of air-conditioning and poor lighting provokes some criticism from the participants. After managing only narrow wins at [[Siegen]] and [[Skopje]], the Soviets reassert their pre-eminence at Nice, winning convincingly with 46/60, to silver medalling Yugoslavia's 37½/60. Third place is shared between the USA and Bulgaria with 36½/60. Bulgaria's excellent showing can be partly explained by the incentives offered by their federation. A team medal of any kind would have earned each player a car, but they just miss the bronze on tie-break. Anatoly Karpov, Boris Spassky, Tigran Petrosian and [[Mikhail Tal]] take home individual gold medals for outstanding performances on their respective boards, while Viktor Korchnoi and [[Gennady Kuzmin]] must settle for bronze. Petrosian scores 12½/14 for an 89.3% performance, the best of the event. [[Michael Stean]] picks up the $1000 Turover Brilliancy Prize for 'best game of the Olympiad' against Walter Browne. [[Wolfgang Uhlmann]] coins the phrase "One is permitted to lose to Karpov with Black" after suffering defeat in their round 4 encounter. *[[Tony Miles]] wins the 13th [[World Junior Chess Championship]], held in Manila, after narrowly missing out the previous year to [[Alexander Beliavsky]]. Miles' good form keeps him on track to becoming England's first grandmaster. *The 42nd [[USSR Chess Championship]] is won jointly by Alexander Beliavsky and Mikhail Tal (both 9½/15), ahead of [[Rafael Vaganian]] and Lev Polugaevsky (both 9/15). *The annual [[Las Palmas]] tournament results in a win for [[Ljubomir Ljubojević]], whose tally is 11/15. He is a full point clear of second placed pair Alexander Beliavsky and [[Fridrik Olafsson]], both having 10/15. *There is a strong entry at [[Sochi]], where Lev Polugaevsky triumphs at the 7th Chigorin Memorial, with a total of 11/15. Runner-up is [[Alexei Suetin]] (9/15). Polugaevsky continues the winning form he displayed earlier at [[Solingen]], where he scored 10/14, taking the tie-break from Lubomir Kavalek (also 10/14) and finishing well ahead of Boris Spassky and [[Bojan Kurajica]] (tied third on 8½/14). *[[Reykjavík]] is won by [[Vasily Smyslov]] with 12/14, ahead of [[Gyozo Forintos]] (11/14) and, tied in third place on 10½/14, [[Dragoljub Velimirovic]] and [[David Bronstein]]. *Mikhail Tal wins at [[Halle, Saxony-Anhalt|Halle]] in East Germany with 11½/15, ahead of [[Rainer Knaak]] (10½/15) and [[Jan Smejkal]] (10/15). He is also a winner at [[Lublin]] and [[Novi Sad]]. *[[Vladimir Liberzon]] is victorious in [[Venice]], taking first place with 9½/13, ahead of [[Vasily Smyslov]] (9/13) and [[Duncan Suttles]] (8½/13). A strong field includes rising stars [[Ulf Andersson]] and [[Jan Timman]], as well as former USSR Champion [[Vladimir Savon]]. *The [[Hastings International Chess Congress]] has another good turnout of overseas grandmasters. A four-way tie for first place occurs between [[László Szabó (chess player)|László Szabó]], Mikhail Tal, Jan Timman and Gennady Kuzmin (all 10/15). *The 11th [[Capablanca Memorial]] Tournament is held in [[Camagüey]], Cuba. Ulf Andersson wins with 11½/15, from [[Eduard Gufeld]] (11/15). Third place is shared between Evgeny Vasiukov and Rainer Knaak on 10/15. *The first [[Pan American Chess Championship|Pan-American Championship]] is held in [[Winnipeg]]. It is won by [[Walter Browne]] ahead of an otherwise weak field. Browne has an eventful and rewarding year, winning the [[U.S. Chess Championship|U.S. Championship]] in [[Chicago]] for the first of six times, scoring further victories at [[Wijk aan Zee]] and [[Lone Pine International|Lone Pine]], and narrowly losing out to [[Bent Larsen]] at the 2nd World Open in [[New York City]]. *[[Jonathan Mestel]] wins the first ever [[World Youth Chess Championship|World Cadet Championship]], held in [[Pont-Sainte-Maxence]] in France. This is to become a regular and important event in the junior chess calendar and is a forerunner to the World Youth Festivals that expand to cover many more age categories. *Bulgaria's great effort and high placing at the Olympiad is followed by an intensely competitive [[Bulgarian Chess Championship|national championship]]. Held at [[Asenovgrad]], the result is a tie between [[Nikola Padevsky]] and Ivan Radulov (both 10/15), ahead of [[Evgeny Ermenkov]], just a half point off the pace. *The 1st [[World Computer Chess Championship]] takes place in [[Stockholm]]. It is won by the program [[Kaissa]] (USSR), followed by [[Chess (Northwestern University)|Chess 4.0]] (USA), which defeats third placed Ribbit (CAN) in a play-off for second. There are many interesting games and some surprising moves arise from tactical complications. The championship shows that chess computers are making rapid progress, although the quality of the [[Endgame (chess)|endgame play]] is still very poor and poses no threat to human players of average strength. *The [[People's Republic of China]] makes an application for membership of FIDE. *The first chess book published in the United States by a major publisher using [[algebraic chess notation|algebraic notation]] is printed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chess History & Chronology - Bill Wall |url=http://www.geocities.com/SiliconValley/Lab/7378/history.txt |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kfLHqMvc?url=http://www.geocities.com/SiliconValley/Lab/7378/history.txt |archivedate=2009-10-20 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Births== *[[Gata Kamsky]], Russian-American GM and world championship candidate - June 2 *[[Sergei Rublevsky]], Russian GM and former national champion - October 15 *[[Konstantin Sakaev]], Russian GM and former world youth champion - April 13 *[[Matthew Sadler (chess player)|Matthew Sadler]], English GM and former British champion - May 5 *[[Sofia Polgar]], Hungarian IM and WGM, middle sister of Zsuzsa and Judit - November 2 *[[Sergey Volkov (chess)|Sergey Volkov]], Russian GM and former Russian champion - February 7 *[[Igor Miladinović]], Serbian GM and former world junior champion - January 25 *[[Wang Pin]], Chinese WGM and many times national women's champion - December 11 *[[Qin Kanying]], Chinese WGM and many times national women's champion - February 2 *[[Mohamad Al-Modiahki]], GM from Qatar, first Arabic grandmaster - June 1 *[[Artur Kogan]], Ukrainian-Israeli GM who has lived in many countries - January 29 *[[Roland Schmaltz]], German GM and champion of speed chess - November 15 *[[Reefat Bin-Sattar]], Bangladeshi GM, the country's third grandmaster - July 25 *[[Ziaur Rahman (chess player)|Ziaur Rahman]], Bangladeshi GM, the country's second grandmaster - ? *[[Maria Manakova]], Russian born WGM and model, has lived in Serbia - March 1 *[[Ryan Palmer (chess player)|Ryan Palmer]], Former Jamaican champion and coach living in the UK - ?
==Deaths== *[[Rashid Nezhmetdinov]], Soviet master, writer and virtuoso of chess combinations - June 3 *[[CHO'D Alexander]], English IM, wartime codebreaker and former British champion - February 15 *[[Henri Grob]], Swiss master, former national champion and noted correspondence player - July 5 *[[Josef Lokvenc]], Austrian IM and former national champion of Germany and Austria - April 2 *[[Maurice Raizman]], French master and many times the national champion - April 1 *[[Abram Khavin]], Ukrainian master and former national champion - January 19 *[[Eugenio Szabados]], Hungarian-Italian IM and former President of the Italian Federation - March 6 *[[Gottlieb Machate]], German master and former Olympiad player - May 27 *[[Leon Stolzenberg]], American master and leading correspondence player - October 25
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *{{cite book | author=O'Connell, Kevin | title=The Batsford Chess Yearbook | publisher=Batsford | year=1975 | isbn=0-7134-3024-9}} *{{cite book | author=Burgess, Graham | title=Chess Highlights of the 20th Century | publisher=Gambit Publications | year=1999 | isbn=1-901983-21-8}} *{{cite book | author=Keene, Raymond | author-link=Raymond Keene | author2=Levy, David | author2-link=David Levy (chess player) | last-author-amp=yes | title=Chess Olympiad Nice 1974 | publisher=Batsford | year=1975 | isbn=0-7134-2978-X}} *[http://www.olimpbase.org Olimpbase - Olympiads and other Team event information]
{{chess}}

revision.text:
The [[2016 Asia Cup]] was held in [[Bangladesh]] in the '''2015–16 Bangladeshi cricket season'''. The season was to be featuring a tour of the country by [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] but it has been postponed amid security concerns. [[Khulna Division cricket team|Khulna Division]] won the [[National Cricket League of Bangladesh|National Cricket League]] (NCL) championship title for the fourth time and [[Comilla Victorians]] won the revived [[Bangladesh Premier League]] (BPL).
==Honours== * [[National Cricket League of Bangladesh|National Cricket League]] – [[Khulna Division cricket team|Khulna Division]] * [[Bangladesh Premier League]] – [[Comilla Victorians]] * Most runs – [[Shahriar Nafees]] ([[Barisal Division cricket team|Barisal]]) 1,117 @ 62.05 * Most wickets – [[Abdur Razzak (cricketer)|Abdur Razzak]] ([[Khulna Division cricket team|Khulna]]) 66 @ 33.71
==International cricket== {{main article|Australian cricket team in Bangladesh in 2015–16|2016 Asia Cup}} [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] was due to tour [[Bangladesh]] from 28 September to 21 October 2015 and playing two [[Test cricket|Test matches]] but it has been postponed amid security concerns.
[[India national cricket team|India]] beat Bangladesh by 8 wickets in the final of the [[2016 Asia Cup]], held in Bangladesh.
==See also== * [[History of cricket in Bangladesh]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] 2016
==External links== * [http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/bangladesh/content/story/260114.html CricInfo re Bangladesh] * [http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Seasons/2015-16_BDESH.html CricketArchive re tournaments in Bangladesh in 2015–16]

{{Infobox hurling championship | name = 2016 Christy Ring Cup | image = | imagesize = | caption = | dates = 23 April – 25 June 2016 | teams = 8 | champions = [[Meath GAA|Meath]] | count = 1 | champions captain = James Toher | champions manager = Martin Ennis | runners-up = [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]] | runners-up captain = [[Neal McAuley]] | runners-up manager = [[Dominic McKinley]] | matches = 16 | goals = 40 | points = 540 | top scorer = [[Ciarán Clarke]] (2-38) | previous year = 2015 | previous tournament = 2015 Christy Ring Cup | next year = 2017 | next tournament = 2017 Christy Ring Cup }} The '''2016 Christy Ring Cup''' was the 12th staging of the [[Christy Ring Cup]] hurling championship since its establishment by the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] in 2005. The competition began on Saturday 23 April 2016 and ended on Saturday 25 June 2016. [[Kerry GAA|Kerry]] were the [[2015 Christy Ring Cup|2015 champions]] and were promoted to the [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship]].{{citeweb|url=http://www.gaa.ie/gaa-news-and-videos/daily-news/1/0606151905-nolan-inspires-kingdom-to-ring-cup-final-win-over-derry/ |title=Nolan inspires Kingdom to Ring Cup final win over Derry |date=6 June 2015 |work=GAA.ie |accessdate=16 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702063640/http://www.gaa.ie/gaa-news-and-videos/daily-news/1/0606151905-nolan-inspires-kingdom-to-ring-cup-final-win-over-derry/ |archivedate=2 July 2015 |df= }} In the first final on 4 June 2016 a mistake was made in recording the score. [[Meath GAA|Meath]] were presented with the Christy Ring Cup as the final score was believed to be Meath 2-18 to [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]]'s 1-20.{{citeweb|url= http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/scoreline-controversy-overshadows-royal-win-34773095.html|title=Scoreline controversy overshadows Royal win|date=5 June 2016|work=GAA.ie|accessdate=5 June 2016|first=Francis|last=Mooney}} On 7 June 2016 the CCCCCCCC - Central Competitions Control Committee ordered that the final be replayed. Meath won the replay on 25 June 2016 after extra time, beating Antrim 4-21 to 5-17. ==Format== The 2016 [[Christy Ring Cup]] was played in a [[Double-elimination tournament|double-elimination]] format. For clarity, the draw details are detailed in each round below. ==Round 1== All eight teams play in Round 1. {{footballbox collapsible |date = 23 April 2016 |time = |round = Round 1 |team1 = [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]] |score = 3-20 - 0-17 |report = |team2 = [[Kildare GAA|Kildare]] |goals1 = C Clarke 2-10, J Dillon 1-0, C Carson, N McKenna, J Connolly 0-2 each, C Johnson, C McKinley, M Dudley, R McCambridge 0-1 each. |goals2 = G Keegan 0-11, M Fitzgerald 0-2, M Grace, P Divilly, N Ó Muineacháin, B Byrne 0-1 each. |stadium = [[Parnell Park]], [[Dublin]] |attendance = |referee = |stack=yes }} {{footballbox collapsible |date = 23 April 2016 |time = |round = Round 1 |team1 = [[Down GAA|Down]] |score = 2-12 - 1-18 |report = [http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/mourne-mens-late-surge-ends-derry-hopes-34676352.html Report] |team2 = [[Down GAA|Down]] |goals1 = S Farren 0-8 (4fs), O McCloskey 1-0, R Convery 0-3 (2fs), Se McGuigan 0-2 , T McCloskey, P Cleary 0-1. |goals2 = B Byers 1-1, D Toner (2fs), O McManus 0-4 each A O'Prey 0-3, F Conway, J McGrath, C Woods (f), S Nicholson, P Sheehan (f), C O'Prey 0-1 each. |stadium = Owenbeg |attendance = |referee = C Cunning (Antrim) |stack=yes }} ==Quarter-finals== The two losers of round 2A (who won a match and lost a match) play the two winners of round 2B (who lost a match and won a match). These two matches are referred to as quarter-finals. {{footballbox collapsible |date = 7 May 2016 |time = 14:00 |round = Quarter-final |team1 = [[Kildare GAA|Kildare]] |score = 1-17 - 0-15 |report = [http://www.kildarenow.com/sport/kildare-secure-christy-ring-cup-semi-final-spot-after-banishing-exiles/90657 Report] |team2 = [[London GAA|London]] |goals1 = G Keegan 0-9(4f), M Delaney 1-1, J Byrne, P Cocoman and J Sheridan 0-2 each, M Fitzgerald 0-1. |goals2 = K O'Loughlin 0-7(6f), S O'Donnell and M O'Dwyer 0-3 each, C Hickey and M Duggan 0-1 each. |stadium = [[St. Conleth's Park]], [[Newbridge, County Kildare|Newbridge]] |attendance = |referee = |stack=yes }} {{footballbox collapsible |date = 7 May 2016 |time = 14:00 |round = Quarter-final |team1 = [[Down GAA|Down]] |score = 1-14 - 1-7 |report = [http://www.irishnews.com/sport/2016/05/09/news/strong-second-half-showing-sees-down-set-up-meeting-with-ulster-rivals-antrim-513054/ Report] |team2 = [[Roscommon GAA|Roscommon]] |goals1 = C O’Prey (0-4, frees), D Toner (1-0), C Mageean (0-2), B Byers (0-2), S Nicholson (0-2), C Egan (0-1), O McManus (0-1), D Hughes (0-1), C Woods (0-1 free). |goals2 = N Connaughton (1-0), J Fallon (0-2, 0-1 free), J Lawlor (0-2), E Flanagan (0-2), T Fetherston (0-1). |stadium = [[Ballycran GAA|McKenna Park]], Ballycran |attendance = |referee = D Hughes (Carlow) |stack=yes }} ==Semi-finals== The winners of round 2A play the winners of the two quarter-finals. {{footballbox collapsible |date = 21 May 2016 |time = |round = Semi-final |team1 = [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]] |score = 1-24 - 0-23 |report = [http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/antrim-dig-deep-to-scupper-down-34735738.html Report] |team2 = [[Down GAA|Down]] |goals1 = C Clarke 0-16 (12f, 1 '65); C Carson 1-1; N McKenna 0-3; E McCloskey, J Dillon, E Campbell, Conor Johnston 0-1 each. |goals2 = D Toner 0-9 (5f); C Woods 0-4; C Taggart, D Hughes, C O'Prey (2f, 1 '65) 0-3 each; C Egan 0-1. |stadium = [[Loughgiel Shamrocks|St. Patrick's Park]], [[Loughguile]] |attendance = |referee = D Hughes (Carlow) |stack=yes }} {{footballbox collapsible |date = 22 May 2016 |time = |round = Semi-final |team1 = [[Kildare GAA|Kildare]] |score = 0-21 - 1-21 |report = [http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/mcgowan-keeps-the-royals-on-the-march-34737383.html Report] |team2 = [[Meath GAA|Meath]] |goals1 = G Keegan (9f, 1 '65) 0-12, M Delaney, M Fitzgerald 0-2 each; M Grace, P Cocoman, J Byrne, L Quinn and J Sheridan 0-1 each. |goals2 = J Toher (9f) 0-12, G McGowan 1-3; S Clynch 0-3; S Heavey, S Morris and N Heffernan 0-1 each. |stadium = [[St. Conleth's Park]], [[Newbridge, County Kildare|Newbridge]] |attendance = |referee = J Keane (Galway) |stack=yes }} ==Final== The winners of this year's Christy Ring Cup final (tier 2) will be automatically promoted to play in the qualifier group of next year's [[Leinster Senior Hurling Championship]].See motion 24 passed at 2015 GAA Annual Congress 28th February 2015 {{footballbox collapsible |date = 4 June 2016 |time = 17:30 |round = Final |team1 = [[Meath GAA|Meath]] |score = 2-17 - 1-20 |report = [http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/scoreline-controversy-overshadows-royal-win-34773095.html Report] |team2 = [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]] |goals1 = N Heffernan, S Quigley 1-1 each, J Toher 0-5 (5f), A Gannon, J Keena 0-3 each, K Keoghan 0-2, S Heavey, K Keena 0-1 each. |goals2 = C Johnston 1-2, C Clarke 0-5 (1f, 1 '65), J Connolly 0-4, E McCloskey, N McKenna 0-3 each, E Campbell, C McKinley, S McAfee 0-1 each. |stadium = [[Croke Park]], [[Dublin]] |attendance = |referee = J O'Brien (Tipperary) |stack=yes }} ===Controversy=== During the final a point that wasn't actually scored was awarded to Meath on the official scoreboard. At the end of the match the score was recorded as Meath 2-18 Antrim 1-20 and the referee mistakenly confirmed this score. Meath were awarded the trophy. On 7 June 2016 the [[Glossary of Gaelic games terms#C|CCCC]] ruled that the final score was a draw, 2-17 to 1-20, and that the match should be replayed.{{citeweb|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/confirmed-christy-ring-final-between-meath-and-antrim-to-be-replayed-34779686.html|title= Confirmed: Christy Ring final between Meath and Antrim to be replayed|date=7 June 2016|work=RTE Sport|accessdate=7 June 2016}}{{cite web|title=Antrim lose Christy Ring Cup final against Meath after claims of scoreline blunder|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/gaelic-games/36453794|publisher=BBC|accessdate=5 June 2016}} ==Replayed Final== '''Charity donation''' All proceeds from this game were donated to two charities nominated by Meath and Antrim. {{footballbox collapsible |date = 25 June 2016 |time = |round = Replayed Final |team1 = [[Meath GAA|Meath]] |score = 4-21 - 5-17
(AET) |report = [http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/meath-outlast-antrim-in-extra-time-cracker-to-win-christy-ring-cup-final-at-the-second-time-of-asking-34833532.html Report] |team2 = [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]] |goals1 = J Toher 0-12 (0-11 fs); N Heffernan 2-0, S Clynch 1-3 (0-2 fs), G McGowan 1-0, A Gannon, S Quigley 0-2, S Morris, J Keena 0-1. |goals2 = C Clarke 1-5 (0-1 f; 0-1 65), N McKenna 1-5, C Johnston 1-2, D Hamill, J Connolly 1-0, D McKiernan 0-2, N Elliott, E Campbell, S McAfee 0-1. |stadium = [[Croke Park]], [[Dublin]] |attendance = 2,938 |referee = C McAllister (Cork) |stack= yes }} ==Christy Ring/Nicky Rackard Play-offs== ===Bottom play-off=== Contested by the two losers from round 2B. Both these teams lost their first two matches. {{footballbox collapsible |date = 21 May 2016 |time = 3:30 pm |round = Bottom play-off |team1 = [[Wicklow GAA|Wicklow]] |score = 2-23 - 0-15 |report = [http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/moorehouse-the-master-for-wicklow-34737360.html Report] |team2 = [[Derry GAA|Derry]] |goals1 = C Moorhouse (8fs) 1-11; D Staunton 1-3; D Masterson 0-4; M Lee 0-2; P Doran, T Storey, A Byrne 0-1 each. |goals2 = R Convery (6fs) 0-7; M McGuigan 0-3; J O'Dwyer, O McCloskey, M McGrath, D Foley, A Grant 0-1 each. |stadium = [[Páirc Esler]], [[Newry]] |attendance = |referee = J O'Brien (Tipperary) |stack=yes }} ===Relegation/Promotion play-off=== The bottom team in this year's [[Christy Ring Cup]] (tier 2) plays the winner of this year's [[Nicky Rackard Cup]] (tier 3). If the Nicky Rackard champions win the match, they are promoted to next year's Christy Ring Cup in the place of this year's bottom team. {{footballbox collapsible |date = 11 June 2016 |time = |round = Play-off |team1 = [[Derry GAA|Derry]] |score = 1-14 - 1-21 |report = [http://hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=256478 Report] |team2 = [[Mayo GAA|Mayo]] |goals1 = R Convery (0-8, 5f), S Farren (1-3), A Grant (0-2), M McGrath (0-1). |goals2 = K Feeney (0-11, 8f), J McManus (0-4), D McTigue (1-0), S Regan (0-1), K McDermott (0-1), C Charlton (0-1), C Freeman (0-1), D Kenny (0-1), J Cotter (0-1). |stadium = Seán O'Heslin Park, [[Ballinamore]] |attendance = |referee = J Keane |stack=yes }} ==Scoring statistics== ;Overall {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox venue | name = A. Le Coq Arena | nickname = | image = Alecoqarena.jpg | caption = '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA Category 4 Stadium]]'''
[[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] | | fullname = | location = Asula 4c, [[Kesklinn, Tallinn|Kesklinn]], [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]] | coordinates = {{coord|59|25|16.65|N|24|43|55.38|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = 2000 | built = | opened = 2 June 2001 | renovated = | expanded = 2016–2018 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Estonian Football Association]] | operator = Estonian Football Association | surface = | construction_cost = 131 million [[Estonian kroon|EEK]] (2002) | architect = Haldo Oravas | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = FC Flora Lilleküla Stadium | tenants = [[FC Flora|Flora]] (2001–present)
[[Estonia national football team]] (2001–present) | capacity = 14,405{{cite web|title=A. Le Coq Arena|url=http://jalgpall.ee/ejl/a-le-coq-arena|publisher=Estonian Football Association|accessdate=15 August 2018|language=Estonian}} | record_attendance = | dimensions = {{convert|105|by|68|m}}{{cite web|title=A. Le Coq Arena staadion|url=https://www.spordiregister.ee/et/ehitis/3144/a_le_coq_arena_staadion_ja_tribuunihoone|work=Eesti spordiregister|accessdate=15 August 2018|language=Estonian}} | scoreboard = | publictransit = }} The '''A. Le Coq Arena''' (known as '''Lilleküla Stadium''' prior to sponsorship and during [[UEFA]] competitions) is a [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Tallinn]], Estonia. It is the home ground of football club [[FC Flora|Flora]] and the [[Estonia national football team]]. With a capacity of 14,405, it is the largest football stadium in Estonia. ==History== In July 1998, [[FC Flora|Flora]] submitted a planning application to Tallinn City Council, requesting permission to build a new stadium on wasteland between railway lines in [[Kitseküla]], close to the border with neighbouring [[Lilleküla]].{{cite web|url=https://www.postimees.ee/2549619/prugimaest-saab-staadion|title=Prügimäest saab staadion|trans-title=Waste ground will become a stadium|work=Postimees|date=25 July 1998|language=Estonian}} Receiving the council's approval, Flora signed a 99-year lease on the estate and construction began in October 2000.{{cite web|url=http://epl.delfi.ee/archive/fc-flora-rajab-lillekulasse-jalgpallistaadioni?id=50846002|title=FC Flora rajab Lillekülasse jalgpallistaadioni|trans-title=FC Flora will build a football stadium in Lilleküla|work=Eesti Päevaleht|date=19 October 2000|language=Estonian}} The stadium was designed by Haldo Oravas. The stadium was officially opened 2 June 2001, with a [[2002 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2002 FIFA World Cup qualification]] match between [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]] and the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]]. The match saw Estonia's [[Andres Oper]] become the first player to score at the new stadium when he scored in the 65th minute, with the full-time result being a 2–4 loss. [[File:Samba boys kick off the match in Tallinn.jpg|thumb|left|A. Le Coq Arena during Estonia [[Exhibition match|friendly]] against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in 2009]] In January 2002, [[A. Le Coq]] bought naming rights for the stadium and Lilleküla Stadium was renamed A. Le Coq Arena. [[File:AEROSMITH - WORLD TOUR 2007- A.Le Coq ARENA, Tallinn.jpg|thumb|right|[[Aerosmith]] concert held at A. Le Coq Arena in 2007]] Aside from football and other sporting events, several concerts have been held at A. Le Coq Arena, such as [[Lenny Kravitz]] in 2005 and [[Aerosmith]] in 2007. During the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]], the stadium hosted 6 out of 15 tournament matches, including the final. In 2012, Flora completed the transfer ownership of the Lilleküla Football Complex, including A. Le Coq Arena, to the [[Estonian Football Association]]. In September 2016, it was announced that the stadium would host the [[2018 UEFA Super Cup]]. In preparation for the match, the stadium's capacity was increased from 10,000 to 15,000.{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefasupercup/news/newsid=2398008.html|title=Tallinn to stage 2018 UEFA Super Cup|publisher=UEFA.com|date=8 August 2017}} The 2018 UEFA Super Cup match between the [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League]] winners [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and the [[2017–18 UEFA Europa League]] winners [[Atlético Madrid]] was held on 15 August 2018, with Atlético Madrid winning 4–2 in extra time.{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefasupercup/news/newsid=2398008.html|title=Atlético win UEFA Super Cup in extra time|publisher=UEFA.com|date=16 August 2018}} ==Lilleküla Football Complex== A. Le Coq Arena is the centrepiece of the Lilleküla Football Complex, which also includes two grass surface pitches, two [[artificial turf]] pitches and an indoor hall. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|A. Le Coq Arena}} *[http://jalgpall.ee/ejl/a-le-coq-arena A. Le Coq Arena] at Estonian Football Association {{et icon}} *[http://fcflora.ee/klubist/a-le-coq-arena A. Le Coq Arena] at FC Flora {{et icon}} {{s-start}} {{Succession box | title = [[UEFA Super Cup]]

2012–2016 (arena renovations) | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Roanoke | operator = [[Comcast Spectacor|Global Spectrum]] | surface = Multi-surface | construction_cost = $14 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|14000000|1971}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Smithey & Boynton{{cite book |title=Consulting Engineer, Volume 36|year=1971|publisher=Technical Publishing Company}}
Frantz & Chappelear

[[Ice hockey]]: 8,672
End stage: 10,500
Center stage: 10,600
Eclipse: 4,276 | tenants = [[Virginia Tech Hokies]] Ice Hockey
[[Roanoke Maroons]] Ice Hockey
[[Radford Highlanders]] ice hockey
[[Roanoke Valley Rebels]] ([[Eastern Hockey League|EHL]]/[[Southern Hockey League (1973–77)|SHL]]) (1970–1976)
[[Virginia Squires]] ([[American Basketball Association|ABA]]) (1971–1972)
[[Roanoke Express]] ([[ECHL]]) (1993–2004)
[[Roanoke Steam]] ([[af2]]) (2000–2002)
[[Roanoke Dazzle]] ([[NBA Development League|NBADL]]) (2001–2006)
[[Roanoke Valley Vipers]] ([[United Hockey League|UHL]]) (2005–2006)
[[Roanoke Rail Yard Dawgs]] ([[Southern Professional Hockey League|SPHL]]) (2016–present) }} '''Berglund Center''' (originally called the '''Roanoke Civic Center''') is a 10,500-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] located in the [[Williamson Road, Roanoke, Virginia|Williamson Road]] neighborhood of [[Roanoke, Virginia]]. It was built in 1971. It was the former home to the [[Roanoke Dazzle]] [[basketball]] [[team]], as well as the [[Roanoke Express]] and [[Roanoke Valley Vipers]] [[ice hockey]] teams. Currently, it is the home of the [[Roanoke Rail Yard Dawgs]] of the [[Southern Professional Hockey League]], [[Virginia Tech]], [[Radford University]] and [[Roanoke College]] men's [[ice hockey]] teams. The arena is also the home of the annual boys basketball games between Roanoke's two city high schools, [[Patrick Henry High School (Roanoke, Virginia)|Patrick Henry High School]] and [[William Fleming High School]]. == History == Opened in October 1971, the Roanoke Civic Center was also the former home of the [[American Basketball Association (1967-1976)|American Basketball Association]] (1967-1976) professional basketball franchise [[Virginia Squires]]. The Squires played there (in addition to the [[Norfolk Scope]], [[Richmond Coliseum]] and [[Hampton Coliseum]]; all within the state of Virginia) from 1971 to 1972. The Virginia Squires used the Civic Center for only one season due to low attendance, before folding in 1976. [[Elvis Presley]] performed there in 1972, 1974, 1976, and was due to return in 1977, about a week after his death. It hosted 251 [[professional wrestling]] events between 1975 and 2013.[http://wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=shows&sort=ort&land=3®ion=17&stadt=245&arena=652 Shows held at the Roanoke Civic Center, from WrestlingData.com] [[World Championship Wrestling|WCW]] held [[Fall Brawl (1994)]] there and ''[[Monday Nitro]]'' on March 31, 1997. [[WWE]] brought ''[[Monday Night Raw]]'' on December 1, 1997, May 6, 2013, and November 17, 2014. The 1977-1981 [[Southern Conference]] men's basketball tournaments were held there as well. From 2001 to 2006, professional basketball was active again at the Roanoke Civic Center, with the [[National Basketball Association]]'s [[D-League]] franchise, the Roanoke Dazzle. College basketball was also recently contested there, in the form of the [[Big South Conference]] men's basketball tournaments in 2001 and 2002. The [[Metro Conference]] men's basketball tournament was held here in 1991. When both the Dazzle and Vipers folded after the 2005-06 season, the Roanoke Civic Center was left with 60 open dates to fill for the upcoming fall and winter.{{cite book|first=Jon C.|last=Scott|title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South|year=2006|publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.|page=4|isbn=1-894974-21-2}} Eventually, nearly two-thirds of these open dates were awarded to the Virginia Tech, Radford University and Roanoke College hockey clubs, the arena's primary tenants until 2016, when the [[Mississippi Surge]] relocated to Roanoke, becoming the [[Roanoke Rail Yard Dawgs|Rail Yard Dawgs]]. == Overview == Built at the same time as the Scope and Richmond Coliseum, the Roanoke Civic Center is the area's premier sports and entertainment venue. There are eight restrooms and six concession stands at the arena, which has a {{convert|60|ft|m|sing=on}} ceiling height and 10 spotlights as well as a portable stage that is no larger than 60-by-40 feet. There are 8,372 permanent seats at the arena; the arena floor measures over {{convert|20000|sqft|m2}}. The Eclipse forms the Coliseum's half-house configuration. The arena recently began a $6.2 million renovation project expected to last until 2016. The arena's heating system has been replaced, and plans call for upgrades to the arena's electrical system and to all arena entrances, as well as for all seats to be replaced. Adjacent are a {{convert|14396|sqft|m2|sing=on}} exhibit hall with {{convert|10000|sqft|m2}} of column-free space, and a 2,440-seat theatre that can be used for concerts, Broadway shows, the [[Roanoke Symphony Orchestra]] and other special events. The theatre features a {{convert|55|ft|m|sing=on}}-by-105-foot stage; 1,625 seats in the theatre are in the orchestra level, 295 in the loge and 520 in the balcony. After recent renovations, the facility became known as the Roanoke Performing Arts Theatre. A {{convert|46000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} special events center was added to the Civic Center in 2007; it is used for trade shows, meetings, conventions and other special events. It can hold up to 3,066 seated, 5,850 standing. The ceiling height is 32 feet. == Professional sports teams == * [[Virginia Squires]], [[American Basketball Association]] (1971–1976) * [[Roanoke Express]], [[East Coast Hockey League]] (1993–2004) * [[Roanoke Steam]], [[AF2]] (2000–2002) * [[Roanoke Dazzle]], [[NBA G League]] (2001–2006) * [[Roanoke Valley Vipers]], [[United Hockey League]] (2005–2006) * [[Roanoke Rail Yard Dawgs]], [[Southern Professional Hockey League]] (2016–present) * Virginia Iron Horses, [[National Gridiron League (indoor)|National Gridiron League]] (2019–) {{Panorama |image = Image: Roanoke Civic Center interior.jpg |fullwidth = 4226 |fullheight = 1000 |caption = The interior of the arena with its hockey configuration in place for a [[Virginia Tech Hokies#Ice Hockey|Virginia Tech Hokies]] ice hockey game, prior to the 2016 renovations. |height = 200 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.theberglundcenter.com}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Virginia Squires]] | years = 1971 – 1976 | before = [[Hampton Coliseum]] | after = last arena }} {{s-end}} {{Music venues of Virginia}} {{coord|37.280171|-79.935669|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:1971 establishments in Virginia]] [[Category:American Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Virginia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Roanoke, Virginia]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Convention centers in Virginia]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:NBA G League arenas]] [[Category:Roanoke Dazzle]] [[Category:Sports in Roanoke, Virginia]] [[Category:Virginia Squires]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Roanoke, Virginia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1971]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Virginia]]

{{unreferenced|date=January 2014}}{{other}} {{About||the film|The Birdcage|the car|Maserati Tipo 61|the rifle feature|Flash suppressor}} [[File:Kersting - Zwei Kinder vor einem Papageienbauer.jpg|thumb|Two children with parrot cage (painting by [[Georg Friedrich Kersting]], ca. 1835)]] [[Image:Birdcage.jpg|thumb|A cage designed for medium-large parrots, with a playtop.]]
A '''birdcage''' (or '''bird cage''') is a [[cage (enclosure)|cage]] designed to house [[bird]]s as [[pet]]s.
Antique (or antique-style) birdcages are often popular as collectors' items or as household decor but most are not suitable for housing live birds, being too small, improper shape, using unsafe materials or construction. Good quality cages designed for pet birds are more suitable.
==Design and size== In general, the larger and the more active the bird, the larger the cage one should use. The amount of time the bird will spend in the cage each day is also a factor. A bird that is caged most of the time requires far more space than a bird caged only at night.
Some birds have special requirements. [[Amazon parrot|Amazons]] and [[cockatiel]]s prefer horizontal bars, as they like to climb. Messy eaters should have a seed skirt to catch food. Breeding birds may require a nest or breeding box and a larger size cage. Smart birds, like [[parrot]]s and [[crow]]s, need secure latching mechanisms to prevent them from figuring them out, and often require toys and/or play-stands to keep them entertained. Parrots in general tend to gnaw on cages, with larger [[macaws]] known to tear bars from flimsy cages. Zinc coated cages or [[chicken wire]] could cause toxicity to parrots over a number of years.
Most parrot cages are made of wrought iron and painted with a non-toxic paint referred to as powder-coating. A newer trend is cages made of solid stainless steel. Large parrot cages made of stainless steel are costly but will outlast a powder-coated cage by 5 to 6 times. The materials used to build the cages greatly affect the price. While small cages are relatively cheap, large [[parrot]]-sized cages are expensive.
[[File:Eolophus roseicapilla -Billabong Sanctuary-8b.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Galah]] in an aviary with wide bar spacing.]]
==Safety== A cage for a tame pet bird which is allowed out daily should be large enough to allow it to easily extend its wings fully without hitting cage sides or toys or objects within the cage. In some countries, it is illegal to house a pet bird in a cage that does not permit it to spread its wings. Wingspans of common pet birds range from approximately {{convert|12|in|cm|abbr=on|disp=flip}} for a budgie and {{convert|16|in|cm|abbr=on|disp=flip}} for a cockatiel up to as much as {{convert|36|-|48|in|cm|abbr=on|disp=flip}} for the larger macaws. Rectangular cages have replaced rounded cages due to the damaged wings caused by non bird friendly round cages.
Untamed birds which are not allowed out of their cages regularly, such as most finches and canaries, require larger cages that are long enough to permit some flight. The bars should be spaced so that curious birds cannot stick their heads out of the cage and become stuck. The cage should also have non-toxic paint, because birds tend to gnaw at the cage, and if the paint is consumed, they can die from poisoning. [[File:Forgotton Songs Installation, 50 Bird Cages Floating in the Sky.jpg|thumb|Birdcages used in the public artwork [[Forgotten Songs (artwork)|''Forgotten Songs'']], Sydney.]] Cages should also be equipped with appropriate perches. There should be several diameters of perches available, but the diameter should be large enough so that the bird's toes are unable to overlap or completely wrap around the perch. Flight cages and aviaries should be equipped with perches at each end with open space in the middle for flight.
== See also == * [[Aviary]] * [[Aviculture]] * [[Companion parrot]] * [[Forgotten Songs (artwork)|''Forgotten Songs'' (artwork)]] * [[Parrot tent]]

revision.comment: clean up, replaced: British Journal of Sports Medicine. → British Journal of Sports Medicine (2)
revision.text:
{{for|the medical practice|blood transfusion}}
In both [[rugby union]] and [[rugby league]], a '''blood replacement''' (also referred to as a '''blood substitution''' or '''blood bin''') is a special kind of [[substitution (sport)|substitution]] which can be used in the case of a player having to leave the field of play temporarily to have a [[wound]] attended to. Both rugby union and rugby league are physically demanding games, so musculoskeletal injuries are common, as well as injuries to the head and neck, and fractures.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://web.a.ebscohost.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=6728e1e2-7b1e-491f-a527-5f79258a1549%40sessionmgr4002&vid=5&hid=4204|title = Match and training injuries in rugby league.|last = King|first = Doug|date = 1 February 2010|journal = Sports Medicine|doi = 10.2165/11319740-000000000-00000|pmid = |volume=40|pages=163–178}}</ref> During the IRB 2011 Rugby World Cup, a study was conducted to determine the frequency and nature of the injuries sustained. It confirmed that rugby, like many other contact sports, has a high incidence of injury.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://web.b.ebscohost.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=5f53e27e-66f7-4806-bbdc-9864dcd470d5%40sessionmgr111&vid=6&hid=125|title = Rugby world cup 2011: International rugby board injury surveillance study|last = Fuller|first = Colin|date = 2012-04-25|journal = British Journal of Sports Medicine|doi = 10.1136/bjsports-2012-091155|pmid = |access-date = 9 June 2012|volume=47|pages=1184–1191}}</ref>
== Rugby union ==
In rugby union, blood replacements are provided for by Law 3.10 of the [[International Rugby Board]].<ref>[http://www.irb.com/NR/rdonlyres/A1F47EAA-EBD7-43F9-BD4F-64DC7368A6C2/0/060704LGLAWSEN_06_LAW3.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061027193038/http://www.irb.com/NR/rdonlyres/A1F47EAA-EBD7-43F9-BD4F-64DC7368A6C2/0/060704LGLAWSEN_06_LAW3.pdf |date=October 27, 2006 }}</ref>
A player who has been wounded may be replaced for up to fifteen minutes (running time), during which he or she may receive first-aid treatment to stanch the flow of blood and dress the wound. The player may then ask the referee to return to the pitch of play. The return-to-play regulation is a regulation in rugby union that reduces the likelihood of premature return-to-play by injured players. However studies have shown that there is a high rate of non-compliance with this regulation and therefore highlights the need for implementation and dissemination of the return-to-play regulation.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://web.a.ebscohost.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=6728e1e2-7b1e-491f-a527-5f79258a1549%40sessionmgr4002&vid=10&hid=4204|title = Compliance with return-to-play regulations following concussion in Australian schoolboy and community rugby union players.|last = Finch|first = Caroline|date = 1 April 2012|journal = British Journal of Sports Medicine|doi = 10.1136/bjsm.2011.085332|pmid = |access-date = 2011-06-24|volume=46|pages=735–740}}</ref>
== Rugby league ==
In rugby league, blood replacement substitutions are enforced by the referee after he has noticed that a player is bleeding. This change takes the place of one of the allocated 10 replacements that teams are allowed. In the case of misconduct, where the incident leading to the injury has been either placed on report or sin-binned or sent off, then the replacement is free (does not count) however when the player returns this counts as an interchange. The blood bin was first used in 1991.
== Gamesmanship ==
Fake blood injuries have been used for tactical benefit, to enable teams to withdraw a player they may wish to bring back on later. A notable example was the "[[Bloodgate]]" incident, where [[Harlequin FC|Harlequins]] wing [[Tom Williams (rugby player, born 1983)|Tom Williams]] came off the field with what turned out to be a faked blood injury in order to facilitate a tactical substitution. An investigation by the ERC and the RFU revealed that blood injuries had also been faked by Harlequins to enable tactical substitutions on four previous occasions. These findings resulted in a four-month ban for Williams, a three-year ban for former director of rugby Dean Richards and a two-year ban for physiotherapist Steph Brennan as well as a £260,000 fine for the club.<ref>{{cite web|author=Simon Austin |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/simonaustin/2009/08/bloodgate_brings_deano_down.html |title=Sport: Simon Austin: Bloodgate brings Deano down |publisher=BBC |date=2009-08-18 |accessdate=2010-02-09}}</ref>
== References ==

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport | image=chaza.jpg | imagesize=200px | caption=A Chaza match at [[Nariño Department]] | union= | nickname=Tenis Pastuso (Pastuso Tennis) | first= 15th century | registered= | clubs= | country/region=[[Colombia]] and [[Ecuador]] | contact=No | team=4 players each team | mgender= | category=[[Racquet sport]] | equipment=[[ball]], [[racquet]] | venue= Outdoor | olympic=No | paralympic=No }} [[File:Lachazapuerres.jpg|thumb|Some people playing Chaza in [[Puerres]] [[Colombia]]]] The '''Chaza''',<ref>{{cite web|title=Juegos Autóctonos de Pasto|url=http://www.culturapasto.gov.co/index.php/component/content/article?id=256:juegos|website=Cultura y turismo de Pasto|date=26 February 2014|language=Spanish|access-date=2015-01-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105103346/http://www.culturapasto.gov.co/index.php/component/content/article?id=256:juegos#|archive-date=2015-01-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> '''pelota nacional''', or '''national ball''',<ref>{{cite web|last=López|first=Paúl|title=La pelota nacional, un deporte de nuestra cultura|url=http://www.voltairenet.org/article163177.html|website=Red Voltaire|date=1 December 2009|location=[[Quito]]|language=Spanish}}</ref> is a [[Colombia]]n [[racket (sports equipment)|racquet]] [[sport]], (like [[tennis]]), which is practiced on a rectangular area bounded by lines. This area is divided by a line drawn on the floor that divides the playing field. It is played between two teams, each with 4 players. The object of the game is to launch a [[ball]] (called "bombo") by hand or racquet so that it bounces into the opponent's field without being returned.
It is an old sport, created before the fifteenth century, by Precolombian people. The sport is widely practiced in [[Nariño Department|Nariño]], [[Colombia]], and is the [[national sport]] of [[Ecuador]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Tenis Pastuso en el Ecuador |url=http://www.voltairenet.org/article163177.html|language=Spanish}}</ref>
== History == Chaza was created in the 14th century by [[indigenous communities]] who inhabited the area that is currently on the border of [[Colombia]] and [[Ecuador]]. In the beginning it was played with a heavy [[leather]] ball, which was thrown by hand.
== Game Rules == [[File:Bombo de chaza.jpg|thumb| Bombo ([[racket (sports equipment)|racket]]) for Chaza]] This game can be played with hands or with a wooden [[racquet]], The ball is lined with goatskin and called a "bombo" weighing 70-90 grams.<ref>{{cite web|title='Chaza', un deporte típico de Pasto|url=http://expedicionrcn.noticiasrcn.com/videos/chaza-un-deporte-tipico-de-pasto-expedicion-6591|website=RCN Televisión|date=20 May 2014|language=Spanish|access-date=2015-01-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105232858/http://expedicionrcn.noticiasrcn.com/videos/chaza-un-deporte-tipico-de-pasto-expedicion-6591#|archive-date=2015-01-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> [[File:Bola vasca.jpg|thumb|Ball for chaza]] As in [[volleyball]], players rotate, which is why the field has a line (6 on each side) indicating which position each should play.
Points are scored as for [[tennis]], i.e., 15, 30, 40 and the point. When a team gets 6 points and maintains a minimum difference of 2 points over their rival, it wins the set. When a team wins 2 sets, it wins the game.
Each point is also scored as in tennis, looking for the opposing team to fail to return the ball before it bounces 2 times within their field.
The field is rectangular and concrete and 110 meters long and 10 meters wide, divided by a line drawn on the ground.
== See also ==
* [[Sport in Colombia]] * [[Sport in Ecuador]] * [[National sport]] * [[Tejo (sport)|Tejo]] * [[Tennis]] * [[Volleyball]] * [[Pelota]]

[[Vine City (MARTA station)]] | coordinates = {{Coord|33.758|N|84.401|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = November 22, 1989 | opened = September 6, 1992 | closed = June 9, 2017{{cite news|last1=Tucker|first1=Tim|title=Georgia Dome implosion date set|url=http://www.ajc.com/sports/football/georgia-dome-implosion-date-set/uJTjDe07LxuGOU5xyKBt6H/|accessdate=June 12, 2017|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution}} | demolished = November 20, 2017 | owner = Georgia World Congress Center Authority | operator = Georgia World Congress Center Authority | surface = [[FieldTurf]] (2003–2017)
[[AstroTurf]] (1992–2002) | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]214 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|214000000|1992}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[Heery International]]; [[Rosser International|Rosser FABRAP International]]; and [[tvsdesign]] | structural engineer = [[Weidlinger Associates]][http://www.columbia.edu/cu/gsapp/BT/DOMES/GEORGIA/g-cable.html Cable Top Football] ''Columbia University'' | project_manager = Barton-Malow | general_contractor = [[Skanska|Beers]]/Georgia Dome Team | former_names= | tenants = [[Atlanta Falcons]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]) ([[1992 Atlanta Falcons season|1992]]–[[2016 Atlanta Falcons season|2016]])

[[Georgia State Panthers football|Georgia State Panthers]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) ([[2010 Georgia State Panthers football team|2010]]–[[2016 Georgia State Panthers football team|2016]])
